body:
This course is all about how to choose and connect all the marketing options you have into a coherent campaign, measuring what works and using that information to make decisions.


By the end of this module, you’ll understand how to :  


  • Identify and measure ''qualified'' or ''good'' traffic 
  • Set realistic marketing goals
  • Estimate how much it will cost to achieve your goals
title: Text Title

body: In this video, Salim Virani talks through the basic steps in the customer's buying journey - from becoming aware you exist to having a deeply engaged relationship where you repeatedly buy and advocate for the product.
instruction: Click on the video to find out more
title: The Customer Journey - Basic Steps

_media._source: C7M1 : Welcome - Customer Journey + Kickstarter from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body:
Throughout this section we’ll look at the case study around Triggertrap, a tool that allows you to automate different actions with your camera, so you can get professional looking shots without the professional price tag.


Sadly, like other startups before it, Triggertrap folded in early 2017. You can find more details about this here. However, before this, they provided a great example of how you can generate growth for your business through digital marketing.


We'll focus on an earlier successful campaign they ran to get people to donate to their crowdfunding effort on Kickstarter.
title: Text Title

body:
In order to set realistic traffic goals, we'll need work backwards from our business target.


Haje’s business target was raising £50,000 on Kickstarter. His average pledge was £100, meaning he’d need 500 people to fund him. So how many people did he need to land on his Kickstarter page?


What we need to work out is the conversion rate between the people who land on Haje’s site, and those who actually end up parting with their money at the end of it.


For this we need a benchmark. To find a benchmark we can use a range of different sources, including industry averages, published case studies or simply asking someone who's done something similar. In this case, Kickstarter has published it's average conversion rate is 2%, so we can work with that number as our benchmark.


If we ultimately need 500 people to buy, Haje would need to drive 25,000 people to his site and convert them to funders at a 2% conversion rate in order to achieve his goal.
displayTitle: Working backwards - how much traffic will you need?
title: Working backwards - how much traffic do you need?

_media._source: C7M1 : Trigger trap by the numbers v2 from DBAVideo on Vimeo.
video7-1.8 Projections from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

displayTitle: How much traffic do you need to break even?
body:
Now that we know how to work out how many people we need to come to the website, we can start to put a figure on how much marketing spend that might cost and take a step back to see if it sounds realistic.


The formula for traffic required is :

Traffic required = target revenue / average spend / conversion rate


If for example, marketing budget is £1,000 and target revenue is £5,000, you might need to ask yourself a question along the following lines :


Can we get 125,000 visitors and convert them to customers at a rate of 0.4%, for £1,000?
instruction: Click on the video to find out more
title: The Customer Journey - Basic Steps

_items.body: We can look to industry averages, which give us some broad sense of what’s realistic.
_items.title: Industry Averages
Specific Case Studies
_items.body: We can also look to specific case studies, often marketers point to their sales results or results of past campaigns. We can then look at the results of campaigns similar to our own and use those as a benchmark.

_items.title: Previous Company Experiments
_items.body:
The last tool is an analog- what companies have come before us which have tried to market a similar product or target a similar customer group. They may not have published their numbers, but so long as you’re not directly competing with them, you’ll be surprised how open companies can be when you reach out to them.

Chances are they’re willing to share- and you can always throw them an incentive (cappuccino, latte, americano?).

_items.title: Where Can You Find Benchmarks?
_items.body:
These websites might well be able to help :


kickstarter.com/help/stats

mailchimp.com/resources/research/email-marketing-benchmarks/

alexa.com

quantcast.com


Search for your industry, and "average conversion rates" or "conversion benchmarks". Conversion depends on channels, and website conversion rates are hard to benchmark.

displayTitle: How do you know what conversion might be?
body: Remember that to work out your conversion rate we need a benchmark. There are at least 3 places where you can find relevant benchmarks:
instruction: Click on the boxes to find out more
title: How do you know what conversion might be?

body:
As we have seen, bringing in traffic costs money but what really matters are the customers who buy.

For Haje only 2,000 people out of the hundreds of thousands who landed on his page ended up buying. This is what we call quality traffic.
displayTitle: Increasing conversion by focusing on quality traffic
instruction: Click on the video to find out more
title: Increasing conversion by focusing on quality traffic

_media._source: C7M1 - 1.5 Trigger trap by the numbers v3 from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

title: Increasing conversion by focusing on quality traffic

_media._source: C7M1-1.6 Trigger trap by the numbers v4 from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body: Trigger Trap's buyers came from 3 sources - PR, Kickstarter and direct traffic (people typing in the web page's URL directly on their browser). In this video, Sal explains more about each of these groups.
displayTitle: Where did Trigger Trap's quality traffic come from?
instruction: Click on the video to find out more
title: Where did Trigger Trap's quality traffic come from?

_items.body:
If we want someone to move from awareness of your product to trusting you, we want to see some form of engagement- this may just be measured by a click onto your site.


Example : Get the latest woodworking tricks in our newsletter.
_items.title: 1. Moving from awareness to trust

_items.body: But from trust to an on-going relationship we often need the customer to sign up to something- this may mean subscribing to a newsletter, or following you on Facebook on Twitter, but either way it allows you to communicate with them again.
_items.title: 2. Moving from trust to ongoing relationship

_items.body:
At the next stage we’re asking them to buy.


Example : 'Spring cleaning? Buy our DIY shelving kit.'
_items.title: 3. Closing the deal

body:
Once your traffic starts coming in, it is important to get as many of your visitors to convert as possible by encouraging them to move through the customer journey. E.g.: Click on Facebook ad, sign up to newsletter, add item to wishlist, add item to shopping cart.


As you plan your customer journey - from the layout of your landing pages to the messages in your ads - make sure you are being clear to the customer what action you want them to take next. 


The type of message will depend how advanced customers are in their buying journey.
displayTitle: Increasing conversion with Calls to Action
instruction: Click on the right arrows to explore some examples of ''calls to action''
title: Narrative Title

_items.body: You build a following- you create champions and build a community around you. This is really hard to measure, but your presence in the community is crucial, as it allows people to know where to find you so they can get behind you too.
_items.title: Community
Reputation
_items.body: You build a reputation. The more you market the more people start to take you seriously as a credible source. This helps not just with sales but also with general business opportunities.

_items.title: Dialog
_items.body: You start a dialog- it creates an opportunity for people to give you feedback, helping you decide if you’re heading in the right direction and giving you the chance to refine your message and offering where you need to.

body: As well as the measurable benefits of marketing like the number of people becoming aware of your products or the number of people purchasing, there are a lot of un-measurable benefits to marketing that can help you achieve your longer term goals.
instruction: Click on the boxes below to find out more
title: Unmeasurable benefits of marketing

body: There’s also one other benefit to unmeasurable marketing- It’s called the Spill-Over Effect. In the Spill-Over Effect “traction” in one channel gets used to start another channel.. Blogging and conferences are other ways to generate further attention and PR.
title: Spillover effect

The steps in the customer journey are :


  • Awareness
  • Caring
  • Engagement
  • Buying

The steps in the customer journey are Awareness, Caring, Engagement and finally Buying.

_feedback.correct:

title: Q 7-1-2 Ordering Title

body: Which of the following statements describes a source of ''high quality'' traffic?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure? 


High quality traffic refers to streams of people who visit the website where a high proportion end up purchasing!

_feedback.correct:
That's correct! 


High quality traffic refers to streams of people who visit the website where a high proportion end up purchasing!

_items.text: A source that has brought in the biggest number of customers for relatively low ''cost per click'
A group of customers with high disposable income
A group of customers where a high proportion ended up purchasing.

title: Q 7-1-3 High Quality Traffic

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure? 

 

You need 20 people to spend £50 to make your £1000 budget. Only 1/100 people (1%) who land on your website buy. Therefore to find 20 ''buyers'' you need 20x100 visitors.

_feedback.correct:
Thats right! 


You need 20 people to spend £50 to make your £1000 budget. Only 1/100 people (1%) who land on your website buy. Therefore to find 20 ''buyers'' you need 20x100 visitors.

_items.text: Can I get 2000 visitors for £100?
Can I get 20,000 visitors for £100?
Can I get 2000 visitors for £1000?

body:
Imagine your boss wants you to run a campaign for his online gift shop. You are told that :


  • Your target revenue is £1000
  • Your average item sold is £50
  • Your average conversion rate is 1%
  • Your marketing budget is £100


What is your key sense-check question? 


Reminder : Traffic required = target revenue / average spend / conversion rate
title: Q 7-1-4 MCQ Title

body:
Wherever you can put yourself in your customers' shoes - they will be at different phases of the journey towards buying from you. Your marketing should make it clear what you want to them ''do'' next and calls to action can help you do this. 


High quality traffic is traffic where a high proportion of people end up buying. Don't get distracted by high volume, low quality traffic. 


To set realistic marketing goals and budgets, you can work backwards - how much money do you need to make? how many visitors do you need to buy to make that money? What conversion rate do you need for your predictions to work?
title: Text Title

body:
Running good campaigns requires you to work out who your customers really are so that your traffic is as high ''quality'' as possible and you don't waste money advertising to people who will never end up buying. By the end of this module, you will understand how to : 


  • Listen to your audience 
  • Target your ads at your audience 
  • Set up tests to keep making your proposition more appealing and profitable!
title: Text Title

body: How did they know to sell posters? In this video, Rich Brown, co-founder of A Great Little Place and it's successor Great Little Prints explains how they built a community on Facebook listened to what they liked, then discovered what a viable product for them might be.
displayTitle: Founder Stories : A Great Little Place
instruction: Click on the video to find out more
title: Founder Stories : A Great Little Place

_media._source: C7M2 : Great Little Place Interview from DBAVideo on Vimeo.
<iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/222518948" width="640" height="360" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>

body:
Great Little Place grew from a simple Facebook page into a successful poster selling business. 


They used Facebook to target the right customers and quickly understand what those customers liked. This allowed them to create posters they knew their target market would love and buy. 


They were also able to build up the momentum to continue drawing in customers, achieving a high click through and purchase rate.


After only a few years of optimisation they achieved a twenty time ROI (return on investment). So for every £1 they spent on Facebook ads they were able to generate £20 in sales.
instruction: Click on the video to find out more
title: Text Title

displayTitle: Testing which product would work best
body:
Great Little Place had the sense that posters would sell and they knew what content to put on those posters, but they still didn’t know exactly which posters would work best.


Facebook allowed them to try advertising different versions of posters, changing the image, headlines, descriptions to test which sold best.


In the images below show that the black and white image of London with the blue river massively outperformed the other posters, including the same image of London with the pink river.


To this day they don’t know why it was so much more successful - but they don’t need to! They learnt exactly what they set out to learn-- which poster was the most popular.


So now that’s the poster they advertise most and that’s the poster that gives them their very strong return on investment in their marketing.
title: Testing which product would work best

_source: C7M2 : Testing from DBAVideo on Vimeo.
body: In this video, we see what Facebook testing looked like for A Great Little Place
instruction: Click on the video to see the story
title: Testing & Tuning

_items.body:
Facebook insights analysed the people who liked their page and was able to tell them that generally, women were more likely to buy posters than men. It also said that women aged 24-34 were their main audience.


So they adapted- they told Facebook to stop showing the adverts to men and only target women. Since they got a higher conversion rate, they got more bang for their advertising buck on Facebook.


Facebook and some other advertising platforms automatically display the ads which get the most % clicks. By focusing on the correct niche, they also got displayed more often.
_items.title: Age and Gender preferences

_items.body: But it doesn't stop there. As well as age and gender Facebook knows everything you’ve “liked”. So you can target based someone based on their “likes” e.g.: Advertising a poster of Brixton to someone who ''likes'' several cafés in a specific area.
_items.title: ''Likes''

_items.body: You can also target people on life events, like people who’ve just got a job, or just become single.
_items.title: Life Events

_items.body:
One last thing which is hugely powerful is friend of a friend targeting. When people see an advert they can see that their friend also likes what’s being advertised- this social proof is hugely effective at raising conversion rates.


Great Little Place tried two identical adverts- the only difference was that one adverted targeted a friend of a friend. That advert performed far better. Changing your target customer can completely transform your performance.
_items.title: Friends of Friends

body:
When a customer ''likes'' your page, you can see the information on their profile. This will give you golden data on who they are and what they like. 


Here are 4 ways A Great Little Place used data from their followers' Facebook profiles to understand more about who they are and what they might want.
displayTitle: How Facebook can help you find your best customers.
title: How can Facebook help you to find your best customers?

_media._source: C7M2 - Targeting from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body: Facebook allowed Great Little Place to see what kind of person was most likely to ''like'' their page, and what type of person was most likely to buy their posters. In this video, Rich explains more about their approach to targeting.
instruction: Click on the video to find out more
displayTitle: How can you target your customers?
title: How can you target your customers?

body:
Online advertising offers a lot of different capabilities for tuning your campaign. With Facebook and a lot of other platforms they offer the ability to auto-test and auto-tune how things are working.


Testing all your target groups, all your creative (copy, descriptions, pictures), and all of the permutations of what you want to show your customers manually would take forever. Facebook allows you to plug them all in quickly and easily. It’ll then tell you which combination is the best performer.
instruction: Watch the video to find out more
title: Fine tuning your campaign

_media._source: C7M2 : Tuning from DBAVideo on Vimeo.
C7M2 : Metrics from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body: So with all this data, what should you measure so that you know how your paid adverts are performing and how you need to improve them? In this video Sal talks you through some examples.
instruction: Click on the video to find out more
title: What should you measure?

_items.text: Conversion

body: Which metrics could be used to measure performance at different stage of customers' journey?
instruction: Choose the best answer for each question then click submit
title: Q 7-2-3 - What to measure?

body:
Paid advertising platforms allow you to analyse your followers' data. This allows you to run highly targeted marketing campaigns so a higher proportion of the people who see your ads end up engaging and buying your product. 


This will not only means less money gets wasted advertising to people who won't buy, it will also keep the ad platforms happy. They will reward successful ads by displaying them more often and charging you less.


Many platforms will automatically run tests for you e.g: to see which messages get the most engagement. However, you should track metrics across your unique customer journey to see exactly what needs improving E.g.: ''Customers are ''liking'' the post with our new product but not clicking on the link to our website - why might that be?''
title: Summary

body:
By the end of your module, you will understand how to


  • Design content that helps your community 
  • Build relationships with your community 
  • Share your content where it will be seen
  • Measure your content's performance
title: Text Title

body:
Daniel started a blog called Swombat - a blog offering early stage start-up advice. A couple of years later, Daniel started Grant Tree, a business which helps start-ups get government funding. 


Daniel started his blog before his business, but both had same audience. In fact, it was through his blog that Daniel developed his entire business network, including all his start-up friends. 


He also used it to build up his industry reputation- to the point where high profile advisors found him and reached out to him purely because they liked his posts.
instruction: Click on the video to find out more
title: Case Study : Grant Tree & Swombat

_media._source: C7M3 from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body: Clickbait is online content that attracts people's attention with provocative headlines even though they are not backed up by the content. E.g.: A sure fire way to lose 5kg overnight.
title: Graphic Title

_items.title: Where do we need to put our posts so our target audience can find them?

body:
Make sure you don't only focus on getting people to read your content. You may have catchy headlines but if the content isn't helpful or memorable, you won't turn your readers into customers and might even damage your brand.


The 3 questions to the left are keys to good content :
title: Useful content : Key questions

body:
Hosting your content on a popular platform like Medium gets you lots of views immediately. However, the reader will associate some of their gratitude towards that content to Medium rather than to you. When they get to the bottom of the article, they will also be ushered to the next one.


Publishing content on your website will take longer to attract visits, for example through SEO as people google questions that your article answers. However, those visitors can be more easily encouraged to become customers.
instruction: Click on the video to find out more
displayTitle: Hosting content on your platform vs a blogging platform
title: Text Title

_media._source: C7M3 : Ownership from DBAVideo on Vimeo.
C7M3 - Communities from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body: In this video, Sal explains how Trigger Trap built a loyal community who helped them raise their crowdfunding target in record time.
instruction: Click on the video to find out more
title: Building a community

_items.body: Build relationships with real people - attend meet-ups from meetup.com, go to conferences, follow bloggers, meet them for coffees, read industry magazines. Build networks with your customers so you really understand them.
_items.title: Show up in real life

_items.body: Some people in communities are loud - they blog, tweet, evaluate existing products. Reach out to them and give them a reason to be loud about you (in a good way)!
_items.title: Build relationships with loud people
Follow up - always
_items.body: Set up alerts so that whenever people comment on a post you share on Facebook, Tweet about you or attend one of your events, you reach out with a personal thank-you.

_items.title: Help them - for free
_items.body: Write content that helps them, set up events for them to network and learn useful things, support causes they care about, run competitions, let them use your office space - pitch in!

body:
Do you remember Triggertrap our first case study? It was a photography app. They shared helpful content online to build a loyal community of followers subscribed to their email newsletter, Facebook feeds, twitter account. 


When they launched their crowdfunding campaign for £50k, they raised that amount in 12 hours from their loyal following. Here are some tips for building a community.
instruction: Click the blocks below to find out more
title: Tips : Building a community

_items.backText:
Narrow funnel newsletter

This is a newsletter targeting a smaller group that's a better fit for your business. It allows you to drive them right through your marketing funnel to the buying process, increasing conversion rates.
If you’re constantly focusing on a small market with a similar product you’ll probably want a narrow funnel - to focus on driving people through and getting a specific audience in.

Fat Funnel Newsletter

Trying to increase awareness as much as possible, i.e. getting as many people onto your email list as you can- but don't forget this will lower your conversion rate.If you’re going to be moving around within the market a lot, something like Groupon which targets a lot of different people with a lot of different products, you’ll probably want a fat funnel. You'll accept lower conversion rates because you need your awareness to be as high as possible for future sales.

body: Newsletters can help us to stay in touch with customers until they are ready to buy. It can be months or even years between the time they find out about you and the time they need to buy your product. Here are two approaches to newsletters you might consider :
instruction: Click on the cards to find out more
title: How can you use

body:
Haje was hugely selective about who made it onto the Triggertrap newsletter list: you had to buy a product or add your name to a waiting list before he’d add you.


Otherwise, you would have to be keen enough to dig through his site for it. By keeping his list focused on the customers rather than the highest numbers Haje knew he had a truly good fit with the people on his mailing list - they cared. He could market to them and drive them through to sales.


Swombat's focus has also proved hugely successful as they have 1000 email subscriptions all agreeing to receive up to 5 emails a day. This type of commitment shows that these people must be a very good fit.
displayTitle: Case Studies : Using newsletters to build community
title: Text Title

_media._source: C7M3 : Email & Inbound from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body: Once you have made your content that will help customers, how can you make sure it gets found? Sal shares his ideas in this video...
displayTitle: How do you publicise your content?
instruction: Click on the video to find out more
title: How do you publicise your content?

_items.title: Posting as and when you need to
_items.body: As and when: Haje only writes for Triggertrap when he has something important to say.
Proactive strategy: You decide upfront what to write about. This allows you to prepare a list of ideas so that when you sit down to blog you don’t waste time wondering what to write about.
_items.title: Proactive Strategy
Frequent & Scheduled
_items.body: Frequent and scheduled: Daniel writes for Swombat a couple of times a day, always in reference to the big start-up posts of that day.

Reactive Strategy: this is often better for attracting attention. Watch what’s popular in your space- in blogs, on Twitter and in Facebook. You then quickly write a blog post which addresses that issue. Not only does this provide you with ample material to avoid writer's block but, as the first commentator on current affairs in your industry, you also put yourself and your company at the centre of debate, establishing yourself as a thought-leader and building a great reputation for your startup.
_items.title: Reactive Strategy

body: Here are some helpful ways to plan your content & community strategy :
instruction: Click on the boxes to find out more
title: Accordion Title

_items.title: Measurable Indicators of Performance
_items.body:
• How many people are finding out about us?
  • How is our reputation improving- how many people are writing or posting about us?
  • How many are joining our lists and following us?
  • Are we developing two-way relationships? Do we follow up with those who subscribe to our newsletters and do we convert them to sales?
  • Sales
  • Quality traffic- traffic that drives all the way through to a purchase either of a product or subscription

• Non measurable - most valuable
  • Contacts
  • People who read a post and forward it via e-mail
  • Interesting opportunities
  • The network and community we build, and finding we have champions
_items.title: Non-measurable indicators of performance

body: Here are some of the things you could track as metrics of your content strategy. You will be putting a lot of effort into it so it is important that you feel it is worth your time.
instruction: Click on the boxes to find out more
title: Is your content strategy working?

Immersing yourself in your customer's world and giving other community members recognition e.g.: By sharing their blog posts can build deep, long term relationships better than a ''hard sell'' approach. In the long term, this can build a loyal fan base.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Immersing yourself in your customer's world and giving other community members recognition e.g.: By sharing their blog posts can build deep, long term relationships better than a ''hard sell'' approach. In the long term, this can build a loyal fan base.

_items.text: Reaching out to the ''loudest'' people like bloggers or group leaders and finding opportunities for them to ''shout'' about you
Sharing other people's blog posts on your blog
Meeting people who aren't active online e.g.: Teachers, professors in your field
Setting up online alerts so you know when news / press websites talk about you and you can thank them
Following up with every customer who engages with your content e.g.: Likes your Facebook post or comments on a new product photo
Taking every opportunity to pitch to potential customers while you have them in front of you
Going to trade shows and industry conferences

body: Which of the following can help you build a community?
instruction: Pick 6 and click submit
title: Q 7-3-2 Building Relationships with community

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


Blogging platforms like The Huffington Post can reach a large audience immediately. The down side is that you might not reap the long term SEO or brand benefits. It depends what you are trying to achieve and how quickly.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Blogging platforms like The Huffington Post can reach a large audience immediately. The down side is that you might not reap the long term SEO or brand benefits. It depends what you are trying to achieve and how quickly.

_items.text: You get traffic faster
Your own brand is more strongly associated with the expertise you are sharing and can soak up the gratitude better!
You can signpost readers to browse your core website with products after they have read the article.

body: Which of the following is a benefit of posting on a blogging platform like Medium or The Huffington Post rather than on your own website?
instruction: Choose a statement and click submit
title: Q 7-3-3 Where to share content?

body:
Creating and sharing great content is a great way to build a community of loyal fans. 


You can publish content on your own website and share links to the content on platforms like Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest, Linkedin. Alternatively, you can publish content on external blogging platforms and newsletters. 


You can also build your community offline, attending as many industry events as you can, win over influential people in the community and responding whenever someone shows you love online. 


Always expect to give support and share other people's insights before trying to sell to anyone.
title: Launching a new product

body:
Now that you understand how to make content, SEO will help that content to get found through Google and other search engines. By the end of this module, you will understand : 


  • What SEO is 
  • What you can do to get your content found on Google
  • How you can use SEO to reach specific customers with specific messages
title: Intro

_items.title: What are people actually searching for? What Google search words and phrases do we want to appear for?
What content can we create on our website that helps customers?
How do we generate backlinks from other websites?

body: A good SEO strategy should answer the following 3 questions :
title: What does an SEO strategy contain?

_media._source: C7M4 - Search Engine Optimization from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body: In this brief video, Sal from Founder Centric explains how Search Engine Optimisation works.
displayTitle: How does Search Engine Optimisation work?
instruction: Click on the video to find out more
title: How does Search Engine Optimisation work?

_items.body: This is the traffic which comes from a small number of very popular search terms e.g.: Rings, Bracelets, Jewellery UK, Gold jewellery. The volumes might be large but a smaller proportion of people will be looking for exactly what you sell.
_items.title: The head
The long tail
_items.body:
This stream of traffic comes from small numbers of people but searching for very specific thinks like Gold choker with green emerald, Liza Minelli bracelet or SS17 Lara Johannson earrings in pink gold. 


Even though traffic numbers are smaller, those visitors are more likely to become paying customers.

body: SEO traffic takes a while to generate.  Don’t do anything in the first 3-6 months. But after that it should start to pick up. Your SEO traffic will generally come through 2 different streams.
instruction: Click the blocks below to find out more
title: Types of SEO traffic

body:
Headlines are very valuable for SEO. They display in the search results and encourage people to click. You can input your ''headline'' for each page or ''title'' in the back end of your website or using easy, free plugins.


When writing articles for your blog in particular, consider the following tips for engaging headlines : 


  • Refer to the person using the word “you” in the headline itself.
  • Call it a “How To…” (See Triggertrap for some great success here)
  • Ask questions
  • Include numbers or statistics
  • Use analytics to test different versions of headlines for the same article and build on the version which gets the most engagement. 


For example, the image opposite shows the search results for ''Flower Subscription Service London''. Clear headlines instantly tell me if the content on the page is relevant and interesting.
title: Writing great headlines

_media._source: C7M4 - Buying+intent from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body: Commercial intent is a way to describe how far a customer is in their buying journey. When designing content for your website and blog, it is important to consider customers's needs across the whole journey. For example, if you are selling laptops online, consider creating content to attract customers with low commercial intent e.g.: A guide to buying a laptop for customers searching for ''What should I look for in a laptop'' as well as creating content for customers with high commercial intent e.g.: Buy Macbook
instruction: Click on the video to find out more
title: What is commercial intent?

body: When choosing which keywords, make sure you are reaching out to customers across their buying journey - from the first steps e.g.: ''What to look for in a laptop'' - to the final steps e.g.: ''Buy Macbook Air 13'' Online''. By thinking like a customer you can work out what they might search for, what they would want to see and where they would want to see it.
displayTitle: Reaching customers across the purchasing journey
instruction: Click on the video to find out more
title: Reaching customers across the purchasing journey

_media._source: C7M4 : Needs+and+goals from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

title: Case Study : SEO for a leather sofa cleaning product

body:
By putting yourself at the right place at the right time, you can help your customer and become a part of their lives. This image shows the search results for the query ''How to clean a leather sofa''. We can see that several cleaning products have created useful content to capture potential customers before they are specifically looking to buy. 


Think about your product- whatever it is you’re selling- and ask yourself the following questions:


  • What need, or job, or goal is in your target audience's life even before they know your solution is available?
  • What are they looking for then?
  • What are they trying to figure out?
displayTitle: Case study: SEO for a Leather Sofa Cleaner
title: Case study: SEO for a Leather Sofa Cleaner

body: In this video, Sal explains more about how Google chooses which pages to display for which keywords and how you can encourage search engines to put your pages on top of the pile.
instruction: Click on the video to find out more
title: SEO Deep Dive: Relevance

_media._source: C7M4-Relevance from DBAVideo on Vimeo.
<iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/222526087" width="640" height="360" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>

body:
A final trick to boost your credibility on a given topic is to include the keyword you want to rank on within your domain name.


E.g; If you sell dog toys, choose Hannahsdogtoys.com rather than Hannahs or Hannahs playroom. 


If you can have a matching domain (URL) and twitter name this will give you double credibiilty in Google's eyes. 


Tools like ''Lean’s Domain Search'' help you to find free URLs with the keywords you need. To check if Twitter handles are free, you can use Domainr.
instruction: Click on the video to find out more
title: Choosing a relevant domain

body:
Over time, search engines have become more and more sophisticated at making results relevant to you. They use your previous searches, location, pages you’ve visited, and often have access to information on your social media sites. 


This means that the exact same search carried out by two different users, can generate completely different results. 


That means that Googling your targeted keywords from your own browser might not give you an accurate picture of how your website would rank against competitors to most people or how it would be displayed. Some good tools to use for this are Google Keyword Planner and SEMrush.
title: How Google tailors searches

body:
Besides relevant, credibility is the other big factor that Google uses to decide where to rank your website.


To prove our credibility to the search engines we need to generate backlinks. There are links pointing from another website to content on our website.


Some sites are more trustworthy than others e.g.: BBC News is viewed as more credible than a blog created a few days ago. The more credible the source of our backlinks, the more Google will trust and respect our website - putting it higher in the search results. In this video, Sal explains more.
instruction: Click on the video to find out more
title: SEO Deep Dive: Credibility

_media._source: C7M4 - Credibility & Backlinks from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


A good keyword model combines head terms, tail terms and terms that reflect different levels of intent to buy.

_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?


A good keyword model combines head terms, tail terms and terms that reflect different levels of intent to buy.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


A good keyword model combines head terms, tail terms and terms that reflect different levels of intent to buy.

body: When choosing keywords to target, it is good to choose a mix of keyword types. For each keyword type below, pick the example that fits best.

title: Q 7-4-1 Matching Title

body: Which 3 factors does Google use to decide which pages to put at the top of the search results?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


Google primarily uses relevance, credibility and searcher preferences to choose which pages to display.

_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?


Google primarily uses relevance, credibility and searcher preferences to choose which pages to display.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!


Google primarily uses relevance, credibility and searcher preferences to choose which pages to display.

_items.text: How relevant your webpage is to the search term based on the keywords in your content / domain /
How credible your website is based on which other sites are linking to it
The preferences of the searcher based on their location and what they have clicked on in the past
How expensive your products are

displayTitle: How to get found on Google
instruction: Choose 3 then click submit
title: Q 7-4-2 How to get found on Google

body: Imagine you sell vegan food online. What content is most likely to capture traffic for ''vegan lunch ideas'.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


Try to answer your customer's question as directly as possible. They will decide within seconds whether your content is useful or relevant to them.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Try to answer your customer's question as directly as possible. They will decide within seconds whether your content is useful or relevant to them.

_items.text: 5 vegan alternative to classic lunches
Alternatives to eggs in vegan baking
Why be a vegan?

displayTitle: Targeting specific customers with specific messages
instruction: Choose one and click submit
title: Q 7-4-3 MCQ Title

body:
SEO can help you attract both people searching for topics where we are experts and people who are searching for a product right now.


A good SEO strategy answers 3 key questions: 


  1. How we can be helpful and what keywords we want to target.
  2. What content we have to create in order to actually help.
  3. Who we need to link to us to make us credible.
title: Making your marketing plan

body:
By the end of this module, you will be able to: 


  • Name some of the popular tools to support your marketing campaigns
  • Differentiate between different types of marketing content
  • Select the most appropriate marketing tools to match specific situations
title: Text Title

_media._source: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/222527301" width="640" height="360" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>

_items.body: Facebook may have extremely broad coverage and be great for targeting, but let’s not forget about other tools.
_items.title: Facebook
Google Adwords
_items.body: Google Adwords is great for finding people with intent. It’s expensive but you know that your ad budget is being spent targeting people who are already searching and ready to buy. Remember you can include keywords which involve intent like “shop” to perform even better.

_items.title: Twitter
_items.body: here are also other advertising platforms like Twitter- when you advertise on Twitter you can get immediate results and great success auto-testing.

_items.title: LinkedIn
_items.body: LinkedIn advertising is great for targeting professionals and job seekers, though it can be expensive.

_items.title: iAd
_items.body: iAd also allows you to target people on apple products.

body: For paid marketing there are a lot more options than just Facebook.
instruction: Click on the video to hear more then click the boxes to explore each option
title: Managing paid ads

body:
Some of the bigger communities have sub-sections and sub-communities like Reddit, LinkedIn, Flipboard and Quora.


There are also websites for specific communities like mumsnet for mums, Hacker News for startups, Product Hunt for product designers, Designer News for designers.


Be careful not to be too self-promotional, but as long as you also include other links which are relevant to that community you should find you are very welcome in these communities.


One great example of the power of online communities is a lawyer who attracted 400 high quality visits by demonstrating his expertise by answering questions on Quora alongside links to his website.
instruction: Click on the video to find out more
title: Building Communities

_media._source: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/222528427" width="640" height="360" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>
<iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/222529952" width="640" height="360" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>

body:
A lot of internet channels are content-specific: they require you to create content for them, or require a specific type of content.


Youtube is the best example of this. It’s the second most searched site in the world- but you have to produce video content to post on it.


Other sites are all about images- for example Instagram or Imgur


Slideshare is great for sharing, you guessed it, slideshows.

Medium is a good place to repost blog content to get attention, but remember you don’t own your blog on Medium.
instruction: Click on the video to find out more
title: Sharing Content

body:
There are different reasons to want to inject something with a little traffic. 


You may want to give a blog post a kick start, or to test a landing page so you can split test different options before you promote more widely. One of the most convenient ways to do this is to utilise websites where you can build your own following. 


Sites like Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn and Pinterest are all great for this. Building up a following may take some time investment- but it’s a worthwhile asset because later, when you need that traffic, you have an easily accessible base of followers, you can then redirect their attention to a landing page or blog post to get feedback fast.
instruction: Click on the video to find out more
title: Building a following

_media._source: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/222530063" width="640" height="360" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>

<iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/222530158" width="640" height="360" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe><iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/222530158" width="640" height="360" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>

_items.body:
Mailchimp - fully featured, allows you to run html campaigns, plain tests, split tests, and automated campaigns like drip campaigns that send specific messages over time. It’s free to start, up to about 2,000 subscribers.


If Mailchimp has too many bells and whistles and you find yourself getting distracted….


TinyLetter- simpler than Mailchimp allowing you to focus on writing great content and building up your subscribers.
_items.title: Options for mailing lists
Options for Podcasts
_items.body:
You can’t ignore the iTunes Store. 


It’s the #1 podcast directory out there. There is however, a great tool to use if you’re new to podcasts and overwhelmed by all you have to learn to produce one.


PodBean tries to automate some of the tools that other podcasts require you to learn, especially for audio and editing.

body: Here are some handy tools for managing newsletter and podcasts.
instruction: Click on the boxes to find out more
title: Merging Mail & Podcasts

body:
For making your own website or webpage there are a lot of really simple and great tools out there.


Squarespace and Strikingly: Easy to use and well-designed.


Unbounce: A/B testing pages to see which one is better received. 


Wordpress: The biggest blogging platform


Ghost: A growing UK content platform


A word of warning!  There are a lot of different content management systems out there. Most of them are overcomplicated and will actually slow you down.


A good idea here is to break your problem down and use a series of smaller sites and more specific tools for the exact marketing job you have.
title: Making websites

_items.title: Eventbrite
_items.body: Eventbrite allows you to post events. These listings can sometimes attract traffic to your event if it’s featured.

_items.title: Meetup
_items.body: Only for repeated meetups but its great for building up a following or audience in a place, especially a niche audience around one particular category.

Plancast- allows you to see where your friends are going.

Lanyrd- specific to conferences.
_items.title: Plancast
Attending.io
_items.body: Attending.io- if you’re in the UK and running free events you should definitely be using this one- it’s one of the upstarts here and it’s got a great community around it.

body: As we saw earlier in TriggerTrap’s case, not all marketing can stay completely online. Often you’ll need to run or visit trade shows or events. Luckily there are a lot of online platforms that can help you with offline events.
instruction: Click on the boxes to find out more
title: Events

_items.title: Paypal
_items.body: Paypal: This is a brand which people in the US and in the UK particularly, know and trust. It charges you a percentage for the transaction.

_items.title: Stripe
_items.body: Stripe: this is a new system coming up. It’s much slicker, more polished and easier to use.

Certain product categories also have specialised payment providers. These will do everything from show the product, to run the transaction for you, and record the customer information. e.g.: Gumroad for books


t’s worth looking for different providors who run transactions around your product category. They often have better conversion rates and a few other benefits which help set them above the standard Paypal or Stripe conversion .
_items.title: Other specialised payment providers

body:
Chances are your business will need to charge money.

Here are a couple of ways to charge online:
instruction: Click on the boxes to find out more
title: Payments

_media._source: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/222530308" width="640" height="360" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>

displayTitle: Click on the video to find out more
title: Video Stream Title

body: In order to manage your campaign you need to be able to see exactly what’s going on. Here are some great sites for analytics:

_items.title: Google Analytics
_items.body: GoogleAnalytics - this is a standard analytics tool for you website. It’s free, you install code on your website and can then track where people are coming from and what content they’re reading.
Driftrock - To see how Facebook campaigns work, how they drive 'likes' and sales, this is a really useful tool.
_items.title: Driftyrock

_items.body:
Intercom.io - Looks at the users on your website. This requires you to add a bit of code which tells it individually which user is which. After this it allows you to message them at specific points, segmenting them based on their behaviour. This is great because it gives you the power to auto-message people who get stuck within the marketing funnel, or email visitors who haven’t come back to your site.

VWO (visual website optimiser) - Allows you to create different options for your site and split test.

All of these together help you gain insight into what’s happening right through the marketing funnel.
_items.title: Intercom.io
Hootsuite
_items.body: Hootsuite - for different types of social media. This tool allows you to both manage and measure your social media posts.

instruction: Click on the boxes to read more
title: Analytics

Google Ads monitors the performance of your ads in Google's search results. This is the point in the journey were customers are experiencing a trigger to buy or finding out you exist, so at the beginning of their journey.

Data from your analytics allows you to draw many rich insights including how well traffic from different sources is converting and where there might be specific opportunities to increase conversion.


Too much data without a specific question in mind could be confusing or distracting.

_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?


Data from your analytics allows you to draw many rich insights including how well traffic from different sources is converting and where there might be specific opportunities to increase conversion.


Too much data without a specific question in mind could be confusing or distracting.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Data from your analytics allows you to draw many rich insights including how well traffic from different sources is converting and where there might be specific opportunities to increase conversion. 


Too much data without a specific question in mind could be confusing or distracting.

_items.text: You can identify the right questions to ask like why are so many of my customers dropping off after landing on the ''sweatshirts'' category page? Maybe there is a bug or the content is off-putting or unclear
You can gather masses of customer data on everything they do
You can see which sources of traffic are bringing in the most ''qualified'' leads because you can see where each customer came from and who went on to buy.

body: Which of the following are significant benefits of analysing your website's traffic with tools like Google Analytics?

title: Q 7-5-2 Measuring marketing performance with Paypal

Hootsuite is a popular tool for monitoring your brand's presence on social media and managing your social media content.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Hootsuite is a popular tool for monitoring your brand's presence on social media and managing your social media content.

_items.text: Tracking social media performance
Tracking payments
Identifying your bestselling products

body: What is Hootsuite particularly useful for?
instruction: Choose a statement and click submit
title: Q 7-5-3 Hootsuite

body:
There are many tools out there to help you measure, test and evaluate your marketing strategy. Make sure you never just use them for the sake of it, they should always be solving a specific problem you are tackling with you campaign - helping you to find out something specific that you need to know rather than distracting you with data you don't need. 


Good luck!
title: Summary
